tasks: Create a simple wireframe for a login page using the 8-point grid system, focusing on balancing visual elements and clear typography. (Reference: Redesign your portfolio's navigation using the 8-point grid system)
Write down 5 usability heuristics from nngroup.com that you're familiar with, and explain how they relate to your current design process.
Conduct a self-assessment of your current portfolio's navigation, identifying areas where you could improve user flow. (Reference: Redesign your portfolio's navigation using the 8-point grid system)
Create a low-fidelity wireframe for a product page, focusing on error states and clear calls-to-action. (Reference: Create 3 wireframes for a checkout flow, focusing on error states you missed)
Apply Tesler's Law to redesign your current design elements, aiming for improved aesthetics while maintaining usability.
Research Hick’s Law and create a simple diagram illustrating how it applies to your design process.
Create a high-fidelity wireframe for a product page, incorporating principles of Aesthetic-Usability Effect. (Reference: Apply Tesler's Law to redesign your current design elements)
Develop a simple strategy document outlining how you would approach a new project, using the Laws of UX as a reference.
Conduct 2 user interviews and document 5 pain points using the Jobs-to-be-Done framework.

Create a comprehensive design strategy document for your portfolio, incorporating principles from Product Thinking & Strategy. (Reference: Develop a simple strategy document outlining how you would approach a new project)
Redesign your current design elements using the Laws of UX as a reference, aiming to improve both aesthetics and usability.
Develop a final capstone project that demonstrates your understanding of Product Thinking & Strategy in action.

resources.readup: As an Explorer UX designer, you have the power to shape the user experience and drive business growth by bridging the gap between users' needs and a product's capabilities. To unlock your full potential, focus on developing a strong foundation in UX fundamentals, UI craft, and collaboration, while continuously refining your skills in user research, validation, and product thinking.

resources.title: 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design
resources.description: 7 10 Usability Heuristics for User Interface Design ================================================= Jakob Nielsen ![](https://media.nngroup.com/medi...

topics.name: Understanding Hick's Law and its Application in UX Design
topics.summary: Applying Hick's Law to inform design decisions can improve user experience by optimizing response times.
practice_points: Conduct a usability study on 3-5 websites and analyze the average time it takes for users to complete a specific task, comparing it to the number of options available (Hick's Law).
Create a case study illustrating how Hick's Law can be applied in UX design, including examples from real-world projects.
Design an interactive prototype with varying response times and observe user behavior to validate Hick's Law principles.

topics.name: Developing a Comprehensive Style Guide for Consistency
topics.summary: Establishing a consistent visual language is crucial for effective user experience, and a well-crafted style guide can help achieve this.
practice_points: Create a comprehensive style guide with color, typography, and spacing tokens using Figma or Adobe XD, including examples from 3-5 existing websites.
Conduct an audit of your own portfolio website or a client project to identify areas where consistency can be improved and document findings in a style guide template.
Collaborate with a designer or developer to create a shared style guide for a hypothetical product, incorporating feedback and iteration.

topics.name: Applying the Zeigarnik Effect in UX Research
topics.summary: The Zeigarnik effect can be leveraged to increase user engagement and retention by leaving users with a sense of unfinished business.
practice_points: Conduct 2-3 interviews using the Zeigarnik effect framework, focusing on identifying pain points or unmet needs in users' lives and documenting findings.
Design an interactive survey or questionnaire incorporating the Zeigarnik effect principles to encourage user participation and engagement.
Analyze a real-world product's success story and identify how it leverages the Zeigarnik effect to keep users invested, then create a case study illustrating its application.
